Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `also NN operators should be limited to 1 NN in  max 1 region` <-- this assumes we have at least 64 competent NN ops who also have the time/finances to maintain a NN, and that is not quite the case. I would estimate it's closer to 50. Also, once you are a really good op, and have things automated, it makes sense to expand to multiple regions

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I don't support a total newbie person who has never been a NN op running in 4 regions, and I think most NN ops would look poorly upon that

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and also, it splits your vote and you would probably go mad trying to make it all work, if elected

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content:
I disagree that a YouTube should get a node based on Influence.    This is where I think @Ludom was going yesterday, and I do agree.   I haven’t heard much since then about KMD from said person.   
This whole year I have been excited for these up coming elections as I’ve been a nonstop participant and contributor.  

Really looking forward to many years with KMD.

Content:
Watching the NN channels all year says there’s a lot to do.  
MrLynch and I won’t let the constituents down if we get in.  ❤️

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: If you are thinking about running a NN for the money, let me save you some time: Leave this discord and go live a simple life.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Running a NN is not for the weekend sysadmin, this is a full-time job

Author: mrlynch#5735
Content: my mantra is: focus on the job, get it done right... rewards are just an aftermath

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's nonlinear, as well. Some weeks, nothing happens and everything is groovy. Some weeks there are mandatory updates every few hours to chase down some production bug and it's just madness

Author: mrlynch#5735
Content: not taking 100% btw, i know what the donation address is if u don't take it 😜

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: Like December 2018? :trollface:

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and sometimes the network is fine but your node decided to 💩 the bed and you go debugging things for dozens of hours

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: restarting the NN daemons takes time, and the network takes time to see you. Nothing is short, simple or quick

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: blackjoker spent countless hours sacrificing his uptime to improve the system

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: From what I can tell that dudes been a superhero the past 18 months.

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: As much as one can be going from 0-100 coding skill in such a short amount of time.   Very impressive.

Author: Strob#3417
Content: @dukeleto Just to clarify, by saying it's a full time job I guess you mean you have to be available full time but the real work probably take no more than 25 hours a week? Is that right?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Strob no, what I said

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: just reading the private NN discord channel is a part-time job

Author: Strob#3417
Content: Ok someone else told me lazy nodes put 20 hours a month and the best one 100 hours a month. but you say how many hours a week?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: also, external coins take up a lot of time, and we keep adding more (no thanks to me)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i am not giving any hours/week estimate, there is no average week

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's up to each NN. The less time you spend, the shittier your stats, and the less likely you will be auto-re-elected

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the people that spend very little time per month, they spent hundreds of hours perfecting their automation

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and no matter what, when an external coin breaks, or there is a CVE in BTC/KMD, or 1000 other reasons, you will be a sysadmin in the middle of the night with no warning

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's a full time job

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the best NNs monitor their systems all the time, with notifications to telegram/SMS if bad breakages happen

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: One notary node is about 50 cryptocoin daemons running happily, with iguana glue. Keeping it all working is a juggling act, and usually at least some small part is broken and being researched

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: each NN decided what is worth doing and how often to update

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Updating too often will kill your uptime, so you have to be strategic about it

Author: Strob#3417
Content: Ok so every node is different then? depending on each NN op?

Author: Strob#3417
Content: I thought there was a very precise coordination to get everything the exact same on each node.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Every NN has to run certain coin daemons, and iguana. The way the node is setup, which OS and all that, is up to the admin

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is not good to have identical setups

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then if there is a single exploit, all are vulnerable

Author: Strob#3417
Content: Ok

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: some NN ops use docker, most don't. Some use Redhat iirc, most use Debian/Ubuntu

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I don't think anybody runs a NN on FreeBSD or Windows, nor do I think anybody should try. Unless you are a really special snowflake.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so we are diverse, while also having very stringent requirements for cooperating via NN network

Author: Strob#3417
Content: In you case can you tell me if you could at least get a few contract jobs other than operating your node to make a living or you could just live the whole year with the meager reward?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the NN network uses nanomsg, and so basically, all notary nodes try to keep connections open to others, as best they can. (This is a convenient lie, I am sure James can go into depth about this)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Strob that depends completely on your monthly expenses, location, and future expected expenses

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and skills

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you cant do unix command line, then it will need a lot more time

Author: Strob#3417
Content: haha I wouldn't even think about this if I could NOT use a command line.

Author: Strob#3417
Content: I already have the hardware (I have a rack of 1 u servers meeting the specs) and even many more powerful workstations. a 300MBPS connection on both sides. But I don't think I can spend 40 hours a week only on operating the nodes for the full years. I could spend a few week at 100 if needed. But I also need to work on my regular business VFX 3D and 3D animation business. I can decide how many hours I spend on my regular business most of the time but I can't just stop it. So maybe I can't be a NN operator if it takes so many hours. I maintain my own render farm of 16 computers, ftp server, designed and maintained a few externally hosted websites since 1995. I mined on windows and linux many different coins since 2014. So I am mostly an artist but still highly technical in many aspects (mainly fluid sims and all kinds of VFX, with some scripting in maxscript, melscript, houdini VEX, VOP) but I'm not a coder. So I guess I would need to put a lot more time than most others NN op. I would like to try it for 2 or 3 months and see if I can do it for a full year before proposing. So maybe I will propose next year instead.

Author: jorian#4555
Content: we will set up a testnet (i hope) to see what it is and to show that you're capable

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Strob you sound like a good candidate, if you sysadmin a bunch of machines already

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes do the testnet for NN and you can get a feel for it. if you already are a sys admin, that is most of the experience needed

Author: Strob#3417
Content: But I did it only on windows so far.. But always wanted to switch on linux and started just recently and so far I love it but still not a pro on it.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Sysadmin skills really help in all the day-to-day management of NN servers. Dev skills really help when you are chasing down inevitable bugs/problems, and allows you to sometimes "help yourself" instead of waiting on somebody else to fix it. We have plenty of really good NN ops who are amazing sysadmins, but not developers

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i estimate a NN has about a dozen different git repos, which you must constantly keep up-to-date, compile, reboot and sometimes switch branches between

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: NN ops need to be familiar with git

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: nothing crazy advanced, but the basics
